markdownRemark.html:
We’ve made great progress in being the first to take a conversation diagram in Voiceflow and turn it into an SMS chatbot but our vision of SMS-IT is much greater than that.

Support more Voiceflow Features

Currently we only supported 3 different types of blocks, start, speak and choice blocks. Although these are the main ones required to make a majority of conversations, Voiceflow has other features such as integration blocks to connect to platforms like Google Sheets. Going forward this would require extending our interpreter of VF files within vf-to-ubf to support these blocks.

Support more than just Yes or No Questions.

The main functional requirement for our project was to make a SMS chatbot which could handle a Yes or No answer conversation. Going forward it would be nice if for example a clinician had a chatbot for Physiotherapy and could ask more detailed questions like “How long have you had pain in your kneck for?” where the user responds with “X many days/weeks/months” and we route to the next conversation from a custom user response.

Create conversation tree next to simulator to track conversation flow.

We currently give the ability to test our chatbot but to further solidify this guarantee that the SMS bot works as expect, we thought we could support displaying the conversation tree to the right of the simulator. This means that each time a clinician sends a message to the simulator, the potential outcomes are displayed to them and they can have a full overview of what the conversation structure looks like.

Supporting conversation platforms other than Voiceflow.

The beautiful thing about our project is that with this unified bot format as well as the SMS interface we can take this project further by supporting other platforms like VUIX, Microsoft bot composer and many other platforms who allow you to build a conversation but currently there is no ability to deploy onto SMS.

Making Scaling Simple

Clinicians currently use SMS broadcast platforms like accuRx which allows them to send messages at mass to many numbers. In the future we can integrate these broadcast platforms, which will give clinicians the chance to broadcast a phone number to patients all from our application

Support Internet Services

Despite SMS having a massive reach, one could argue that as time goes on we will transition more to internet services. This is why we built the UBF SMS interface that ubf-to-twilio implements.

Going into the future, we can use this interface to not only support other services such as whatsapp or signal but also allow for alternative SMS platforms to be used other than Twilio. An example of this is GOV.UK Notify which allows you to send emails, text messages and letters to users.
